oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery Interviews Bobby Bare; Ralph Emery Interviews Lee Greenwood Parts 4 and 5
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: There are multiple recordings. The first is of a recording from Ralph Emery (entertainer) interview of Bobby Bare (performer) for the Ralph Emery Show. Second is a recording from Ralph Emery's (entertainer) interview of Lee Greenwood (performer) for the Ralph Emery Show. Tape labeled parts 4 and 5 of the Lee Greenwood interview. Recording is from June 29, 1982.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ralph Emery; Bobby Bare; Lee Greenwood
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Ralph Emery introduces Rosanne Cash's "Ain't No Money" -- (00:10) Emery inquires Bobby Bare about the longevity of "Five Hundred Miles" -- (02:04) Emery invites Bare to discuss "Detroit City" in relation to his live shows; additionally, Emery inquires about Bare's belief his top five records are -- (05:22) Emery reflects on the influence Detroit had in the south during his childhood -- (07:18) Emery and Bare discuss the song-writing abilities of Allen Reynolds and Bare's siblings -- (09:47) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery and Bobby Bare outro voiceover] -- (11:01) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery and Ronnie McDowell introduction voiceover] -- (11:21) Emery introduces "Reggae Cowboy" and invites Bare to explain what reggae is -- (11:54) Emery inquires about why Lacy J. Dalton performed on Bare's album, Golden Memories, but only minimally -- (13:59) Emery believes Bare knows Lee Greenwood and both discuss his growing interest while introducing "I'm Not A Candle in the Wind" -- (16:07) Emery inquires about Bare's enjoyment from movies -- (18:16) Emery and Bare reflect on a time where Bare was around Juice Newton -- (19:26) Emery inquires about who controls the relationship in Bare's marriage -- (21:10) Emery and Bare praise Gene Watson while introducing "This Dreams on Me" -- (21:38) Emery and Bare reflect on Bare's rendition of Willie Nelson and Waylon Jennings' "Mamas Don't Let Your Babies Grow Up to be Cowboys" -- (23:00) Emery establishes Bare's international success and Bare recalls a show he did in Germany -- (25:05) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery and Bobby Bare outro voiceover] -- (26:17) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery voiceover] -- (26:30) Emery and Lee Greenwood discuss how Bare had gone to see E. T. -- (27:28) Emery guesses Greenwood's original first name -- (29:47) Emery and Greenwood discuss how Greenwood had not met Jan Crutchfield before moving to Nashville -- (30:53) Emery introduces "I Just Came Here to Dance" by David Frizzell and Shelly West -- (31:35) Emery inquires about the steps Greenwood had taken to continue his touring career -- (32:55) Greenwood and Emery introduce Watson's "This Dreams on Me" and Greenwood's "It Turns Me Inside Out" -- (33:38) Emery infers that Greenwood will continuously play "It Turns Me Inside Out" and Emery inquires about Greenwood's family -- (36:00) Emery reflects on Alabama's "Never be One" -- (36:37) Emery inquires about Greenwood's fan club and the number of artists that began as writers -- (40:05) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery and Lee Greenwood outro voiceover] -- (41:23) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery and Lee Greenwood voiceover] -- (41:54) Emery and Greenwood discuss Greenwood's shared manager with Mel Tillis, Larry McFadden -- (42:40) Emery inquires about Greenwood's band Lee Greenwood and Blackjack -- (44:08) Emery inquires about Greenwood's dancing influence -- (45:23) Emery recalls a time where Jene Stafford was on the show -- (46:45) Greenwood reveals George Strait was a foreman on a ranch in Texas while introducing "Fool Hearted Memory" -- (47:17) Emery encourages Greenwood to introduce "Broken Pieces of My Heart" and both discuss the energy of Greenwood's songs -- (49:01) Emery invites Greenwood to reveal some of his time in Los Vegas and the budding talents -- (52:20) Greenwood reveals the work that he had done with the Special Olympics with Rex Allen Jr. -- (53:04) Emery and Greenwood express their thanks -- (53:31) Wings of an Eagle [excerpt] (Bobby Goldsboro) [Featuring Ralph Emery and Lee Greenwood outro voiceover]
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Emery, Ralph; Bare, Bobby; Bare, Bobby, 1935-; Greenwood, Lee;
